hints.content: Try to think about $f$ as a transformation of the parent function $y=|x|$.

These are the transformations performed on $y=|x|$ to get $f(x)=\purpleD{2}|x-\greenD{(-3)}|+\blueD{2}$:

1. Shift $\greenD{-3}$ units horizontally (i.e. $3$ units to the left).
2. Stretch by a factor of $\purpleD{2}$.
3. Shift $\blueD{2}$ units vertically (i.e. $2$ units up).

This tells us that the vertex of the graph is at $(\greenD{-3},\blueD{2})$.

It also tells us that if we move $1$ unit to the right from the vertex, we should go $\purpleD{2}$ units up.

In conclusion, this is the graph of $f$:

[[☃ grapher 1]]
Try to think about $f$ as a transformation of the parent function $y=|x|$.

These are the transformations performed on $y=|x|$ to get $f(x)=\purpleD{-4}|x-\greenD{(-1)}|+\blueD{(-3)}$:

1. Shift $\greenD{-1}$ unit horizontally (i.e. $1$ unit to the left).
2. Stretch by a factor of $\purpleD{-4}$.
3. Shift $\blueD{-3}$ units vertically (i.e. $3$ units down).

This tells us that the vertex of the graph is at $(\greenD{-1},\blueD{-3})$.

It also tells us that if we move $1$ unit to the right from the vertex, we should go $\purpleD{4}$ units down.

In conclusion, this is the graph of $f$:

[[☃ grapher 2]]
Try to think about $g$ as a transformation of the parent function $y=|x|$.

These are the transformations performed on $y=|x|$ to get $g(x)=\purpleD{-5}|x-\greenD{(-2)}|+\blueD{2}$:

1. Shift $\greenD{-2}$ units horizontally (i.e. $2$ units to the left).

3. Shift $\blueD{2}$ units vertically (i.e. $2$ units up).

This tells us that the vertex of the graph is at $(\greenD{-2},\blueD{2})$.

It also tells us that if we move $1$ unit to the right from the vertex, we should go $\purpleD{5}$ units down.

In conclusion, this is the graph of $g$:
